body: Sure, will do so tonight after work.

I like the idea but I think we can make it more generic. Perhaps something like what I show here is a desirable prerequisite tweak to Groovy:
https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/312

We could then apply the same idea to your PR to not just supply annotation class names but definitions including any needed annotation attributes?

Used commit c215e5d31922f24b36a26daf123ef293752669bb as a reference and decided against including tests that assert based on timings.  I did test locally and verified that performance for large collections improved substantially and the overhead of converting smaller collections to Sets were negligible.
Any chance you can rebase against master?
may I suggest to move the declaring class check to just before the throw? That way it will not impose a difference to whatever code is using this already right now

My understanding is `org.codehaus` classes are regarded as internal (mostly anyway) so I think we wouldn't have to go through the usual deprecation.
I think it is ok to remove them

+1 to the change itself, but I feel it does not solve GROOVY-7646, because that should have not been happening even without you removing classes from the cache actively. I can for example change the eval script to contain a class besides the script class and then it should blow up again. Furthermore, Eval just uses GroovyShell. So you should get the same problem with GroovyShell too. So in my opinion your fix is not addressing the underlying issue

Given that both 0x and 0X are supported for hexadecimal (similarly 0b and 0B for binary), I have no problem with supporting 0O, but I would expect that we would regard it as bad style, the same way we regard lowercase L bad style for long since it can be confused more easily with number 1. That kind of thing could be allowed in the grammar but flagged as poor style by a codenarc rule.

Hi @blackdrag thanks for the feedback.  I agree with you that this does not address the underlying issue, for that I believe that PR #219 does.  The root problem I believe is that `ClassInfo` keeps a strong reference to it's `Class` so it can never be removed from the static `globalClassValue` weak keyed map making the Class and it's inner GroovyClassLoader reachable.  On a side note, it may also allow us revert to using the Java 7 ClassValue as the default where available.

However, based on what I've seen in the heap dumps, I believe even with fixing the ClassInfo/Class hard ref the Introspector's beanInfoCache (Java problem not Groovy) is keeping soft references to the class which I think means that heap will continually fill up to the point of OOME until those are freed.  My thought with this fix (which may be naive) is that in cases where we know the parsed Class is no longer needed we can do some cleanup to assist the GC and prevent filling heap.

you are very right about the bean cache of course. It is a problem known for years... that and the stupid synchronization mechanism inside the Introspector.  If you now can tell me the performance impact of this change, then I will soon be able to give my ok.

Forgot to mention that my assumption is that `#GroovyShell(GroovyCodeSource)` always creates a unique class/classloader on each call and that no caching is involved based on `GroovyShell#parseClass(GroovyCodeSource)` call to `GroovyClassLoader#parseClass` passing `false` for `shouldCacheSource`.

The only other spot I see where doing this kind of call to the clean-up method is in the `GroovySocketServer` since it creates a unique class/classloader per invocation and never unloads them as reported in GROOVY-3476.
I will try to come up with some reasonable benchmarks in order to assess the performance impact.

With a very [simplistic JMH benchmark](https://github.com/jwagenleitner/testing-groovy/blob/1685d0d72e3f5716410ac605c7f5e888e72156c6/issues/GROOVY7646/src/jmh/java/bugreport/Groovy7646Perf.java) I get the following numbers:

Pre-change:

```
Benchmark                          Mode  Samples    Score    Error  Units
b.Groovy7646Perf.shellEvaluate    thrpt       50  568.820 ? 94.488  ops/s
b.Groovy7646Perf.shellEvaluate     avgt       50    0.004 ?  0.001   s/op
b.Groovy7646Perf.shellEvaluate       ss       50    0.008 ?  0.001      s
```

Post-change:

```
Benchmark                          Mode  Samples    Score    Error  Units
b.Groovy7646Perf.shellEvaluate    thrpt       50  728.420 ? 58.170  ops/s
b.Groovy7646Perf.shellEvaluate     avgt       50    0.003 ?  0.000   s/op
b.Groovy7646Perf.shellEvaluate       ss       50    0.010 ?  0.002      s
```

Not sure the impact under large number of threads, but suspect if there were a large number of threads the impact of throwing OOME's and reclaiming SoftRefs would outweigh the cost of the added changes.  In fact I wonder if that somehow plays into the results above since with the additional changes the speed improved.
Thanks for the feedback, appreciate it.

I found that [`GroovyShell#evaluate(Reader,String)`](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/05e9f5639c9fed6fc3406d594b85aca9892faf76/src/main/groovy/lang/GroovyShell.java#L666) was already trying to do this kind of cleanup using [`InvokerHelper#removeClass`](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/05e9f5639c9fed6fc3406d594b85aca9892faf76/src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/runtime/InvokerHelper.java#L67-L70) for GROOVY-649 as part of commit 5724870025c25622015ba13c0310def5742d0b2f.  So I fixed up this PR to use that and added the call in order to remove the ClassInfo from the globalClassValue cache.  I benchmarked again and am still seeing better throughput after the change.
I cleaned up the PR based on the merging of PR #298 and added javadocs with cautions about ensuring the Class is strongly/softly reachable.  Also added a `getTheClass()` method as suggested.

@hlaaftana if you were interested in adding a test to this PR I think the appropriate place for it would be in [SyntaxTest#testOctalLiteral](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/05e9f5639c9fed6fc3406d594b85aca9892faf76/src/spec/test/SyntaxTest.groovy#L23-L43).  Would also be good to update the [core-syntax.adoc guide](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/05e9f5639c9fed6fc3406d594b85aca9892faf76/src/spec/doc/core-syntax.adoc) in the Octal literal section.
can you explain why you donÂ´t want to mention the diamond problem?

The diamond problem is actually mentioned in one of the following sections. 7604 was just about that the ticket author said that the sub-sentence this PR removes would hint the reader that the following example would be show how to solve the diamon problem, which in fact is not the case.

It's just a tiny correction, I also wont be mad if this ticket is simply ignored and closed.

Forgot to mention that this would also require a [grammar change in groovy.g](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/05e9f5639c9fed6fc3406d594b85aca9892faf76/src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/antlr/groovy.g#L4201).  I think something like following should do but I'm not a ANTLR person:

``` groovy
('0'..'7'|'o'|'O') (('0'..'7'|'_')* ('0'..'7'))?
```

IDE's may report some problems with the syntax, for example in IntelliJ code inspection reports `'0' cannot be applied to (?)` but it still compiles and runs ok.

All rightâ€” sorry about my long absence from this Pull:  I had some problems isolating tests from the collaborators, then managed to let myself fall off the face of the Earth, there.

All that said, I believe we've been able to isolate the tests from collaborators, and get tests that look trustworthy on the public command.

This Pull is rebased from `origin/master` as of today, and implements @PascalSchumacher 's [great suggestion for the minimal interface](https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/286#issuecomment-196498228).  It lives up to the [external truss contract here](https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/286#issuecomment-197187196), but uses a  [GroovyTestCase with collaborator isolation](https://github.com/Dispader/groovy/blob/add_grab_command/subprojects/groovy-groovysh/src/test/groovy/org/codehaus/groovy/tools/shell/commands/GrabCommandTest.groovy).  It exposes a variant of @tkruse 's `reset()` for `PackageHelper`  It leaves off exposing a package reloading command, and GrabResolver specification for another Pull.

What d'y'all think?
+1 for merging then

Thanks for the update. :) 

It looks fine as far as I can tell.

I will merge it there are no objections.

Thanks! :+1:
hmm.... I think this fix goes the wrong way. We have those resolve calls in there for a reason after all. Did you consider fixing the resolve call? Or does that break things everywhere else?

I had tried to fix it in [StatementMetaTypeChooser#resolveType(Expression,ClassNode)](https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/b582ef9bafa92725342797a93a15003a7f9fba1a/src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/classgen/asm/StatementMetaTypeChooser.java#L44) (basically adding condition where originType != primitive) but that broke the build pretty badly.  I sort of figured that from there there would be no way to determine it was only a declaration with an empty RHS expression.  But I'm not knowledgeable in this part of the code, so possible I just didn't apply the right fix.

+1, but also, perhaps checking for blank lines, e.g. by adding an explicit check or a grep() would also be useful (since blank line(s) now seem to be in the file), i.e. something like:
`is.text.readLines()*.trim().grep().each { line ->`
(with the subsequent `def line` no longer required)

I'd also make the comment that runners are the only "module feature" that we check for only within grab rather than when loading the jar. I think we should make it like the other features and always check. But still +1 for the change - just where it is called from would change slightly.
How about `is.text.readLines()*.trim().grep { !(it=="" || it[0]=="#") }.each { line ->` ?

What's the future of this PR?
Maintaining a feature branch with such widespread changes to be conflict free is not rewarding if the outcome is unclear.
Please decide if it should be abandoned at all, if I should just fix the merge conflicts, or if you see the possibility to merge a subset of changes.

I think this pull request is too big. Try splitting it in bunches of <20 files, for example on a per subproject base would already help. And then maybe package path based for src/main. This will allow more people to do the review, and avoids maintenance if more merge conflicts appear.
The discussion raised concernes that we should avoid this kind of change even for private fields. If so, then I don't need to continue. Otherwise I'm fine with rebasing and splitting the PR.
I think it is ok to do for private fields

+1 please get this into 2.4.7

@blackdrag I'm not sure I understand your comment. Dynamic classes are not visited by any static compilation visitor so the bridge method collecting visitor you suggest would have to be run from some other visitor.. or from a statically compiled inner class. The collecting visitor would also have to perform method selection across all of the statically compiled inner classes (or be run after method selection.) 

In any case, I changed the implementation to not add a public method at the cost of possibly misusing phase operations.
I am in two minds about 'borrowing' the Commons IO class and I also haven't done any performance testing as yet. It _should_ be much faster.
I think it's o.k. (and not that uncommon) for apache projects to copy code from other apache projects.

@blackdrag just wondering what you think about the state of this PR, is there something else you think needs to be addressed?  Would be nice to get it in time for a 2.4.7/2.5.0 beta, but if you think the weak ref will cause problems then I can close this.

There has been some recent discussion on the dev mailing list about this under the title [Improve Groovy class loading performance and memory management](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/groovy-dev/201605.mbox/%3C574A999A.3090900%40gmx.org%3E), wanted to link to it from this PR for reference.

I am not too worried about the legality of copying - no problems there. Just the duplication warning bell going off in the back of my mind... Another class to maintain and possibly deprecate should would revamp all such functionality to use a stream-based solution down the track. I guess I should just do some performance tests and if the gain is there, put in some comments to discourage direct usage of the class outside our internal usage.
OK, some local testing gave me about a 20% performance improvement in performance (albeit processing one sample text many times over) with the changes for this PR, so it seems worth putting in.

This is the fix proposed for 2_4_X. I am actually wondering whether for master we actually implement a stricter version which disallows inherited non-abstract methods which clash with static methods. The PR just fixes the inherited abstract method case to avoid the reported `AbstractMethodError`. This would involve removing ClassCompletionVerifier#L100 and tweaking the test for Groovy-4265.
I haven't at this point done anything special for 2.5+. I think we should have the same behavior as Java and reject all static/instance clashes but we can do that as another issue.
proposed PR merged
Merged (including the empty line tweak)
I'm -1 on this one. We already have too many combinations, I don't think adding one more will help.

Note you'd still need `-XaddExports:jdk.compiler/com.sun.tools.javac.api=ALL-UNNAMED` in the GRADLE_OPTS for jigsaw builds for compilations subtasks without a fork, or you need to start all compilation subtasks as forks using `options.fork = true` in the above. Not sure which solution is preferable.
Still needs asciidoc documentation but PR created to solicit any potential early feedback.

There are two kinds f failures wit this one. One is gradle, which needs those switches till Cedrics patch is included. The other is the use of javac in our tests, which should use the compiler API instead. I am basically ok with the patch, since we donÂ´t know wen CedircÂ´s patch is included
